Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: A Benchmark Data Linkage Repository (DLRep)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER award provides pilot funding for a new kind of software repository that could help data scientists create better ways to combine existing data sets. The goal is to encourage collaboration between scientists who consider data methodology, users and builders of integrated data sets, and data custodians. The result may be new high-quality methods for record linkages and better use of existing data. Common, transparent, and reproducible approaches to linkage methodology and privacy preservation will help data analysts meet the highest scientific standards. The project may decrease the gap between research and practice in data science, resulting in better evidence for U.S. policymakers, businesses, and citizens.

The PIs will establish a common benchmarking repository of linkage methodologies, Data Link Repository (DLRep) at the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) at the University of Michigan. Participants in the repository will be able to add comments and ask questions, allowing for engagement between data custodians, providers, producers, holders and data users, as well as between various groups of data users. In addition data users will be able to upload and share code snippets related to the data, allowing for knowledge sharing and better reproducibility. Data users will be able to link related publications and citations via DOI import or by manually entering citation information. This will provide feedback to data providers and other data users about how the data have been used. The repository will accelerate the development of new record linkage algorithms and evaluation methods by providing access to both methods and relevant data. This community effort will improved the reproducibility of analysis conducted on integrated data. The repository will facilitate comparisons of alternative linkage methodologies when using the same and different data, and move forward the provision of privacy-aware integrated data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created LinkageLibrary.org, a platform for researchers engaged in dataset integration, to share and improve their research. Combining datasets is a powerful means of enhancing data and enabling pathbreaking analyses. For example, each Decennial Census has rich information about the social and economic status of American households. Research that links individuals across Decennial Censuses can help us to understand migration, economic and social mobility, and how American families are changing. But standard methods for linking individuals across decades routinely failed to link more than 15% of Americans, resulting in selective and biased samples that were often treated as representative of the country as a whole. Improvements to the linkage process, such as those described in the LinkageLibrary deposit  Automated Linking of Historical Data (Abramitzky, Ran, Boustan, Leah, Eriksson, Katherine, Feigenbaum, James, and Perez, Santiago. Automated Linking of Historical Data. Ann Arbor, MI: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research [distributor], 2020-08-25. https://doi.org/10.3886/E120703V1) result in higher quality, less biased data, and therefore better understanding of our history and the impact of policies on different communities. Continually improving linkage processes is thus critical to unbiased evidence-building.

Different disciplines refer to combining datasets using different terms - data linkage, record linkage, entity resolution, deduplication, entity clustering, object identification, duplicate detection and others. Researchers approach the basic problem in different ways, emphasize different assessments and objectives, and oftentimes reinvent the wheel. Comparisons of different linking methods are rare. Without a community space to share ideas, data, and linking techniques, researchers use sub-optimal data linkage practices or waste time and resources trying to create well-established best practices.

LinkageLibrary provides an interdisciplinary benchmarking repository for linkage methodologies and related data. Researchers can share their linkage algorithms or code and actual or test data used in linkage projects. They can compare their approach to those shared by other researchers, including testing their algorithms on data used by other scientists. Perhaps most importantly, they can talk to each other about their approaches by commenting directly on the code and data shared in LinkageLibrary projects. Thus, the goals of LinkageLibrary is to facilitate the comparison of linking algorithms, helps researchers understand what type of algorithms work best under different conditions and problem domains, promotes transparency and replicability of research, and encourages proper citation of methodological contributions and their resulting datasets. LinkageLibrary brings together the diverse scholarly communities (e.g., computer scientists, statisticians, and social, behavioral, economic, and health (SBEH) scientists) who are currently addressing these challenges in disparate ways.

In our machine learning research, we found that in record linkage, Random Forrest, linear SVM and radial SVM models transfer to new settings (i.e., Machine Learning (ML) models built using one data source, being applied to a totally different data source) much better compared to the Dense Neural Networks. Overall, the SVM models performed best in all comparison experiments. We also found that the radial SVM model benefited the most from adding in the name2vec features (Foxcroft, Jeremy, Adrian d’Alessandro, and Antonie, Luiza. Name2Vec: Personal Names Embeddings. In Advances in Artificial Intelligence, 505–10. Kingston, Ontario , Canada: Springer International Publishing, 2019) with negligible impact on Recall and F1 score. We have released results of our Hybrid Record Linkage research on LinkageLibrary using the mechanism available to connect with an open source Github repository. The results include (1) R code for the different ML record linkage algorithms to train a new model using your own dataset; or (2) the different models trained using a real world health data source in the United States to conduct record linkage on your own data; and (3) code for multiple evaluation criteria to compare results from different methods. Our code will output multiple evaluation measures such as F1 score and Recall to facilitate the evaluation. The details of this work can be found in Ramezani et. al. 2021 or in the presentation video (Ramezani, Mahin, Kum, Hye-Chung, Ilangovan, Gurudev. Evaluation of Machine Learning Algorithms in a Human-Computer Hybrid Record Linkage System, in the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence Symposium - Combining Machine Learning and Knowledge Engineering (AAAI-MAKE) 2021.). These outcomes should contribute to efforts toward a common benchmarking repository of linkage methodologies and the goals of the LinkageLibrary to share, compare, learn, cite, and promote transparency and replicability of research.
